title: Essential Travel English
learningObjectives: Learn basic travel vocabulary for airports, hotels, and transportation
Understand how to ask for directions and help while traveling
Practice common phrases for booking and checking in
Recognize important travel signs and instructions

sections.title: Traveling with English
sections.content: When you travel to English-speaking countries, knowing basic travel English is very important. You will need English at airports, hotels, restaurants, and when asking for directions. This lesson will teach you the most useful words and phrases for traveling.

sections.title: At the Airport
sections.content: The airport has many important places. 'Check-in' is where you show your ticket and get your boarding pass. 'Security' checks your bags for safety. The 'gate' is where you wait for your plane. 'Baggage claim' is where you get your luggage after landing. Important words: passport, ticket, boarding pass, flight, departure, arrival.

sections.title: At the Hotel
sections.content: When you arrive at a hotel, you go to the 'reception' or 'front desk' to check in. You need to show your 'reservation' (booking). Your 'room key' opens your room. If you need something, call 'room service'. When you leave, you 'check out' and pay your bill. The hotel staff can help you with directions and recommendations.

sections.title: Getting Around
sections.content: There are many ways to travel: taxi, bus, train, subway (metro), or rental car. To take a taxi, you can say 'Taxi!' or go to a taxi stand. For public transport, you need to buy a ticket. Always ask 'How much?' for the price. To ask for directions, say 'Excuse me, how do I get to...?' or 'Where is...?'

sections.title: Travel Conversations
sections.content:
Example 1: HOTEL CHECK-IN - 'Hello, I have a reservation under the name Garcia.'

Example 2: ASKING DIRECTIONS - 'Excuse me, where is the nearest subway station?'

Example 3: TAKING A TAXI - 'Could you take me to the Grand Hotel, please?'

Example 4: AT A RESTAURANT - 'Table for two, please. Do you have a menu in English?'

sections.title: Travel Tips
sections.content: Remember these key points: Always carry your passport and important documents. Learn basic phrases like 'Where is...?', 'How much?', and 'I need help'. Be polite and say 'please' and 'thank you'. Don't be afraid to ask people to speak slowly. Keep a translation app on your phone for emergencies. Most importantly, enjoy your trip!

keyVocabulary.definition: An official document for international travel
keyVocabulary.example: Please show your passport at check-in.
I have a reservation for tonight.

keyVocabulary.definition: A ticket that allows you to board a plane
keyVocabulary.example: Keep your boarding pass until you land.
Where is the luggage claim area?

keyVocabulary.definition: Instructions on how to get somewhere
keyVocabulary.example: Can you give me directions to the museum?

keyVocabulary.definition: A car you pay to take you somewhere
keyVocabulary.example: Let's take a taxi to the airport.

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Where is...?' or 'How do I get to...?' to ask for directions. Always start with 'Excuse me' to be polite.
examples: Excuse me, where is the train station?
How do I get to the city center?
Is there a bank near here?
commonMistakes: Using 'Where are...?' instead of 'Where is...?' for singular places

grammarPoints.explanation: Use 'Can I...?' or 'Could you...?' to make polite requests. Add 'please' to be more polite.
examples: Can I have a window seat, please?
Could you call a taxi for me?
Could you speak more slowly, please?
commonMistakes: Using 'I want' instead of 'Can I have'
